However, this could have been just a Balkan War (there had been several wars in the Balkans) - but the German government (or elements of it) took the opportunity of conflict between Austro-Hungary and Serbia to make a bid to dominate all of Europe, The Germans were seriously concerned about the military modernization of France (due to be finished by 1916) and of Russia (due to be finished to 1918) and by the rapid economic development of Russia. The German academic and military elite decided it was “now or never” - either they would destroy rival powers now, or they never would destroy them As Germany would never be in a stronger relative position than it was in 1914 - indeed Germany would (relatively speaking) get weaker over time. So the Germans declared war on Russia sending two letters to the Russian government - one saying that Germany was declaring war because of Russian military mobilization (the gesture of support for Serbia which the Czar had agreed to because his ministers shouted at him), but the other letter delivered by the German ambassador said that Germany would declare war even if Russia agreed to change policy. The German Declaration of War upon France was a tissue-of-lies - it even pretended that the French were bombing Bavaria. Having turned a Balkan War into a general European War, the German government then made it a World War - by invading Belgium, thus bringing Britain into the war. And later launching a campaign against the United States - sinking American civilian ships (killing large numbers of Americans), organizing terrorist attacks in the United States itself, and stirring up some Mexicans against the United States. Eventually, 1917, the United States declared war upon Germany. Franz Ferdinand would have hated all of this - he wanted peace.

At the start of WWI much of the world was under the thumb of colonial occupation and/or emperors. Recall Nicholas II, last tsar of Russia, Pu Yi, the last emperor of China, The last emperor of Germany, Kaiser Wilhelm, Sultan Mehmed VI, the last Ottoman emperor, and finally Franz Joseph the last emperor of the Austro-Hungarian empire. They all had something in common—they were all the last acts in the age of empires, which would soon be over. So what happened to archduke Franz Ferdinand, and why is his assassination another “shot heard ’round the world”? It would seem that the Serbs found themselves under the control of the Austro-Hungarian empire and they weren’t too happy about it. They agitated for self-determination and kicked up enough of a fuss that Franz Joseph sent the archduke and his wife to Serajevo to inspire unity. While parading through the streets, the archduke and his wife were shot and killed by a group calling themselves “The Black Hand”—and here’s where his death is said to spark WWI. Naturally, the Austro-Hungarian empire was furious and demanded that the Serbs turn over the terrorists responsible for the assassination. The ultimatum was delivered 30 days after the assassination and the Serbs were given 48 hours to produce the conspirators. The Serbs either could not—or would not—deliver, but perhaps more importantly, a web of complex alliances was kicked into gear because of this threat. The Russians recognized a kinship with the Serbs because both spoke Slavic languages. The Russians promised their armed support in any event that threatened the Serbs. Here was just such a threat and it caused the unprepared Tsar to mobilize. This alliance was just one of many on the continent that would soon be moved to war as nations and empires mobilized under this complex web of agreements. When the Russian Tsar mobilized his ill-equipped peasant army, it caused the German empire—under the rule of the Tsar’s own cousin—to declare war. Militarized nations, trapped by alliances and imperial tendencies, acted on their growing nationalistic ideals….and the rest is, well, history. It was an unfortunate chain of events sparked by a challenge to authoritarian rule. The conditions were ripe so it is probable that any number of events could have touched off the mobilization of troops—and WWI. At the end of WWI the Russian, German, Austro-Hungarian, Chinese, and Ottoman Empires would collapse. It was bound to happen, regardless of the first victim.

Second, Germany under Bismarck began to evolve into a major world power. While Germany was disunited prior to the rise of Prussia and Bismarck’s influence, Britain and FRance were will to turn a blind eye toward their actions within Germany. It was France’s defeat by Prussia in the Franco-Prussian War, that brought Germany’s military to the attention of Britain. Second, Germany while it was disunited did not have any colonies. By the time Germany united, it was late coming to the European colonialism table. Germany quickly realized that it need a powerful navy, if it was to be seen as a major power and have a colonial empire. Germany started on a massive building of a fleet that could be equal to Britain’s Royal Navy. The British became alarmed at Germany’s progress in building a fleet and its threat to the Royal Navy and Britain’s overseas colonies. This was one of the underlying factors that led the British to declare war on Germany. The other was France seeking revenge for it defeat in the Franco-Prussian War. The Assassination of Archduke Ferdinand was the excuse to make things happen and not the major reason.

By that, I mean there are so many other more important factors to what caused World War I that many historians and political scientists regard it as absurd to equate the death of the heir of a dying, now- insignificant empire (only in name) to being the single cause, or even primary cause, of World War I. Question: Did Franz Ferdinand's assassins set out to cause WWI? No, they didn’t. In fact, a European or worldwide conflict being caused by their actions was likely the furthest thing from their minds when they planned the assassination, or undertook it.Why? They weren’t particularly worldly - Gavrilo Princip and his merry band (and their leaders in the Black Hand Serbian nationalist organization) were not well-traveled and spent the majority of their lives in and around their homeland. The outside world wasn’t something that influenced their thinking.They specifically stated that their aims were limited - Serbian freedom and expansion into Bosnia-Herzegovina to protect ethnic Serbians were their explicit aims. Beyond that, they clearly had no concept.They lived in a world where their perspective was going to be limited - While we in the 21st century take it for granted that we have access to news from around the world, 100 years ago, the majority of people knew about events in their general area and not much more. The concept of their actions creating a greater a conflict would be as alien to them as if in our own time, we thought that an event here on Earth would cause an interstellar war.The assassination itself in the end didn’t cause the war to begin - Historical records demonstrate that the assassination was only a minor blip on the collective radars. In fact, it barely made headlines outside of Austria-Hungary after it occurred. What caused the conflict was and endless series miscalculations and intentional acts of stupidity on the part of leaders in Germany, Austria-Hungary, Russia and France with Great Britain not playing a stronger role in trying to defuse the tension. Even if the assassination hadn’t occurred, war in Europe was inevitable as the tensions and preconceptions required for it were already extant.

The assassination was planned and carried out by members of a secret organization which was almost certainly acting as a proxy for the Serbian government, or for elements thereof. Two of the weaker Great Powers, Austria-Hungary and Russia, became involved immediately. Austria-Hungary sent the Serbs an ultimatum which was consciously written to be defied — that is, it contained terms no government could submit to. The Serbs appealed to Russia and the Russians felt obligated to respond. Had it ended there, the world would have long forgotten the Umpteenth Balkan War. Bur it did not. All the Great Powers had, over tye last few decades, enmeshed themselves in alliances and counter-alliances. As a consequence of this, Germany came in on the side of Austria-Hungary and then France came in on the side of Russia. And even then, had it gone no further, this would probably be remembered as a big but not absolutely devastating war. The world would have probably gone on essentially unchanged afterwards. But then Germany invaded Belgium to get to France and that brought the world's preeminent power, Great Britain. And after that, it had to be the biggest war ever. So the short answer is, Balkan diplomacy and the alliance system.

It lit the fuse, but only because Europe had become a powder keg by the summer of 1914. There have literally been thousands of books and articles written about what happened in those few months—including Barbara Tuchman’s Pulitzer-Prize winning The Guns of August—so instead of giving an in-depth discussion, let me list many of them: A continent armed to the teeth as it had not experienced a major/protracted war in a century (the Crimean War, Wars of German and Italian Unification, and the Franco-Prussian War were pretty small in scope and/or duration).A belief that modern technology would make any war short and relatively bloodless (all because the Franco-Prussian War had been that way and military thinking is that you prepare for the next war by looking at the last one; that “last one” should have been the American Civil War).Growing domestic unrest over the rise of socialism/communism, continued distribution of wealth to the upper classes, challenges to the existing social and religious order, and for Britain troubles with Ireland wanting home rule.Rivalries between Britain/France with Germany over the latter’s desire for an overseas empire of its own; the Germans came late to the party, so there was far less land to claim—primarily in Africa—and thus more tension over what was left.Two defensive alliances in the form of the Triple Alliance (Germany, Italy, Austria-Hungary) and the Triple Entente (Britain, France, Russia) that seemed bent on collision at some point (Italy would remain neutral at the outbreak of World War I and would actually enter the war later on the side of the Allies, as it had territorial ambitions/disputes with Austria-Hungary).Behind-the-scenes intrigue of a diplomatic sort, most famously Austria-Hungary secretly agreeing to support Russian access to the Mediterranean via the Dardanelles in exchange for Russian support of their own annexing of Bosnia-Herzegovina, only for AH to back out once they’d gotten what they wanted.Intense opposition from Serbia over this annexation as it thought that it should have dominion over BH, leading to the creation of the Black Hand nationalist group that would assassinate the Archduke.A series of set-in-stone war plans that had unwittingly set up Europe like dominoes so that in the wake of Franz-Ferdinand’s murder, the triggering of one led to the triggering of all the others.In reality, the rest of Europe was not that concerned about the death of the Archduke; in fact, he was an outcast from his own family for marrying beneath his station. And had the above conditions not existed in Europe at the time, chances are that this episode would have been a mere footnote in history. In reality World War I did not start by itself, it was in actuality the start of what would have been the 3rd Balkan War. Here is my brief summation of what happened.  The First Balkan War was started when Bulgaria, Greece, Serbia, and Montenegro decided to form an alliance, The Balkan League, to counter the growing threat of the Ottoman Empire (Turkey). This was an amazing feat of diplomacy considering how much hatred had existed between some of these Balkan nations. An example would be the constant border disputes between Bulgaria and Serbia over control or division of Macedonia. The partition agreement was finally brokered by Russian diplomats who convinced these two opponents that Turkey was a bigger threat and they should unite against that empire. There was a determination that they had to have a determined response to the Turks and The Balkan League agreed to take the offensive to their enemies. On March 13, 1912, Serbia and Bulgaria signed a treaty where they agreed to give northern Macedonia to Serbia, and southern Macedonia to Bulgaria. The two also discussed a war against Austria as well as Turkey if Austria tried to intervene. In May 1912, Greece and Bulgaria signed a similar treaty threatening use of military actions against Turkey. Montenegro was then added to the league through an informal arrangement with Bulgaria and Greece, and a treaty with Serbia concluded in September 1912. On October 8, 1912, Montenegro declared war against the Turks, and 10 days later the rest of the Balkan League joined the war. After just under a month of heavy fighting Turkey had been pushed back so far that all they could do was try and defend Constantinople. Albania, Epirus, Macedonia and Thrace were now controlled by the Balkan States. Serbia had also reached the Adriatic Sea at Durazzo, which gave them an important sea port. Before this Serbia was a land locked nation that needed a place where they could get supplies that did not have to come through central Europe. Both Austria and Italy were opposed to this acquisition because they feared that a Serbian port on the Adriatic would ultimately become a Russian port for the Czarist Empire. Also, Austria and Italy could not allow this because it might threaten the Hapsburg Monarchy(the Austrian /Hungarian Empire) of which they were a key part. While there were still battles going on at Adrianople, Scutari, and Janina they agreed to an armistice during a peace conference at London in December, 1912. But these negotiations were quickly brought to a close when a coup d’état occurred at Constantinople by some Turkish military officers who were determined to continue the war. While the war was resumed in the spring of 1913 it did not last very long; The Treaty of London ended the First Balkan War on May 30, 1913. The Turks were forced to give over to the Balkan League all possessions in Europe from Enos on the Aegean Sea to Midia on the Black Sea, with the exception of Albania. The major nations of Europe friendly to the Balkan League began to draw the new border of the Albanian State and Turkish sovereignty over Crete was withdrawn and it was united with Greece.  The Treaty followed with a dispute over the spoils of war and caused the Second Balkan War. Greece and Serbia began to conspire an agreement that would split Macedonia leaving Bulgaria out of the picture. Because Bulgaria had suffered the most from the 1st war they felt that they should not be left out. Bulgaria attacked Greece and Serbia. But when the Turks and the Romanians attacked Bulgaria that nation quickly agreed to the Treaty of Bucharest and the biggest victory was by Greece which acquired the important ocean port of Salonica. This also gave many Serbians the idea that they should become independent from that empire. On the morning of June 28, 1914, while traveling in a motorcade through Sarajevo, the capital city of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Archduke Francis Ferdinand and members of his family were assassinated by a Serbian nationalist. The Archduke had ignored warnings of a possible assassination plot and decided to tour the capital on the anniversary of the 1389 battle of Kosovo. This battle was a humiliating collective memory for all Serbs, in which Serbia was defeated by the Turks, ending Serbia's independence as a nation. The Archduke was chiefly chosen as a prime target because of Serbian fears that after he would acquire the throne, he would continue the persecution of Serbs living within the Austro-Hungarian empire. World War I is interesting as there are several factors to consider when discussing the root cause of the conflict. The deep causes of World War I can be reduced to four distinct factors: (1) the multipolar structure of the international system, (2) the rise of nationalism, (3) the cult of the offensive, (4) the rise of Germany as a regional power. The immediate causes can be reduced to 3 factors: (1) the assassination of Archduke Ferdinand, (2) global competition over colonies, and (3) fights over control of the Balkans following the collapse of the Ottoman Empire. The best theoretical explanation of World War I is that it was the result of chain-ganging, i.e., that type of alliance behavior characterized by hyperactive balancing in the form of an unconditional alliance in which State A chains itself to State B, and though its reckless, State B’s survival is seen as indispensable to the security of the alliance as a whole. This is most likely true because from a geopolitical perspective, chain-ganging is most likely to occur in situations where the offensive is perceived to have an advantage over defensive posturing, and it’s common in situations involving a multipolar distribution of power. The alliance dynamics of chain-ganging magnify local disputes, and it makes conquest look easy, leading to the misperception that if State A doesn’t defend or support State B right away, State B will be conquered. In other words, it increases the likelihood for minor disputes to spiral into full-scale war. Another possible causal factor of World War I can be termed the security dilemma caused by the modernization and expansion of Germany’s navy in the first decade of the 20th century. This growth threatened British dominance at sea and led Great Britain to enter a series of alliances, (effectively forming the Triple Entente), and construct the HMS Dreadnought which further accelerated the naval arms race between Great Britain and Germany (culminating in the German navy’s destruction at the Battle of Jutland).

So hellbent even, that the Serb military launched a coup (with public support) against the royal couple, murdered them in brutal fashion, and threw their bodies off a balcony into the street for all to see. This happened, because this particular royal couple was (according to the Serb military and many in the population) on “too friendly” terms with Austria-Hungary, and because they prefered peaceful co-existance over conflict and lust for conquest/expansion. The new king was more eager to gain at least Bosnia-Herzegovina. This is just a nutshell of the things going on between A-H and the Kingdom of Serbia pre-WW1. There was more. The whole thing was a tragedy too, because Franz Ferdinand was a reformer. Once he inherited the throne, he was going to reshape the Austro-Hungarian Empire in a fundamental way. He was planning to give more autonomy to the other ethnicities, and give them rights equal to what the Austro-Germans and Hungarians had. He was also considering to shape the government more along the lines of the US (but still with monarchic traits), and maybe even re-name the whole thing as The United States of Greater Austria. A Danubian Federation like this would have been great for all involved (economically and living standard wise, common defence and safety, etc.), and more importantly would have created a more stable (Central and South-Eastern/Central-Eastern) Europe, and a potent counterweight to Germany (thus stopping the British Island Apes from constantly interferring in/starting wars on the continent to preserve their sacred “balance of power”). Which is why i.e. Churchill and some other English politicians considered creating such a state, after the war. It’s also a reason why Franz Ferdinand was not that popular at court, and particularly disliked by Franz-Josef..

In a nutshell, Ferdinand’s assassination prompted Austria-Hungary to declare war on Serbia. This caused the allies of the two countries to join the conflict followed by their allies and their allies until the war went global becoming WW1.
It was the spark that started the war. A well known domino effect started that could not be stopped.

It was an excuse for the Austro-Hungarian Empire to dismantle Serbia and dominate the Balkans. Serbia refused to along with the Austro-Hungarian demands, and the Russian Empire backed them. Germany backed the Austro-Hungarian’s, and things spun out of control when the Austro-Hungarian’s declared war on Serbia.
